    Head M (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [17th March, 1994],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head M of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Dr John Chen Seow Phun].

    Question again proposed.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Sir, I would like to carry on where I left off yesterday on the subject of waste minimisation. Yesterday, I said that our target, which is to reduce domestic waste from 1.1 kg to 0.9 kg per capita per day, is a stiff target, but it is an achievable one. It is an achievable one if we can get the full cooperation of households in the recycling of the waste. Because currently about 40% of domestic waste is recyclable - papers, cans, glasses. These still end up in our refuse and a large part of our refuse, about 40%, is this type of waste. So if households can cooperate, if the recycling programme can succeed, and we can separate all these materials at source, then that target can be met.

    Dr John Chen also raised two other points - one on environmental auditing and the other on environmental technology. Environmental auditing is a process for companies to assess its own environmental performance and see in what way they can improve upon it. Obviously, in the process of so doing, they will be able to save cost and minimise resources and as a result become more competitive. At the moment, there are no international standards on environmental auditing. But the ISO (International Organisation for Standardisation) recently set up a technical committee to look into this and Singapore is now, through SISIR, keeping track of developments in this area.

Column: 1270



    Dr John Chen also made a point that we should help our companies which have expertise and experience in environmental technology to export this expertise. I fully agree with him. I think this is something that the Ministry is very much in favour of. Obviously, over the years, we have accumulated a considerable amount of expertise in this area. But, more importantly, Singapore, as a country, has shown that we can have economic growth without sacrificing our environment. This experience can be invaluable to other countries which are confronted with the same problem. My Ministry will help local companies in their effort to export this expertise. We can do so by providing them with the contacts and help them to open the doors. We can encourage joint ventures. Recently, we encouraged the business community to set up an organisation to group their resources together to see how they can better cooperate.

    There is a company under my Ministry, SEMES (Singapore Environmental Management Engineering Services), which will explore possibilities of joint ventures.

    On the question of funding for these companies, I think this is a difficult problem on its own. The EDB, I know, operates a comprehensive set of loans, grants and incentives, etc. to companies which can have economic spin-offs in Singapore. Environmental technology (ET) companies also fall under this category, I believe. While there will be no special preference given to environmental technology companies, I think some ET companies have already benefitted from the EDB loans and pioneer status.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun (Hong Kah GRC): Project financing.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Not project financing, but financing on a case-by-case basis.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, can I ask the Minister one question? Are the roadside trees that are chopped down, I believe, in quite large numbers, treated as waste or are they recycled?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: I am not familiar with which trees the Member is talking about.

Column: 1271



     Mr Chiam See Tong: Roadside trees.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: If they are trees in general, the answer is yes, they are recyclable. They can be chopped up and reused.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: No. I want to know whether they are treated as waste and burned away or are they recycled for use.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: They are recycled.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head M of the Main Estimates be reduced by $10 in respect of Code MC 1500.

    Sir, the Ministry has indicated its intention to privatise hawker stalls but has not announced the details of the scheme. The greatest concern that most people have really is whether privatisation of hawker stalls will lead to an increase of hawker food prices. This is a legitimate concern because almost every family patronises hawker stalls. The hawkers themselves are also worried whether they can afford the selling price. I would therefore like to know from the Minister whether they have finalised the sale scheme. Is he able to indicate what kind of prices and discounts stallholders can expect and the ownership period?

    My concern is that if the selling price, translated into monthly rent, is much higher than the current rental the stallholder is paying, there will be pressure on the stallholder to increase his food prices. Could the Minister tell us his view on this?

    I would also like to suggest that once privatised existing restrictions on stallholders should be removed. They should be allowed to re-sell their stalls in the open market or sublet them. Restriction on range of food or produce sold should also be lifted.

     Mr Chin Harn Tong (Aljunied GRC): Sir, the privatisation of hawker centres seems a simple, straightforward exercise. However, the proposed privatisation

Column: 1272

affects other persons besides hawkers and gives rise to other questions. These food centres were erected by the Government to benefit not only the stallholders but also the consumers who patronise the food centres. Sir, I am very much concerned that the Ministry does not adequately provide for the interest of the consumers after the proposed privatisation of the food centres.

    Sir, I anticipate the usual reply of the Ministry will be that free market forces must prevail in the operation of the food centres. The stallholders will lose their investment if they fix their prices too high as the consumers can go to other hawkers. Such a reply ignores the reality that the consumers may not be able to hunt daily for the cheapest hawkers nearest where they live or work because of various constraints. Besides, the stallholders are likely to standardise their prices at the highest level the market can bear so as to defeat any effort of the consumers to save a few cents.

    Sir, a more worrisome question is whether the privatised food centres will remain clean as well as cheap. The tons of refuse that are daily thrown up at these centres are now also removed daily by the Ministry's refuse collection system. The Minister very recently said that this refuse removal service might be privatised soon. If this does happen, it would raise the cost of operating the privatised food centres. Public sector workers are not covered by the Employment Act while the privatised refuse collection workers would be. The stallholders in privatised food centres might try to save cost by not having refuse collected on public holidays and Sundays because of extra pay for workers. I hope the privatised food centres will not turn out to be a threat to our environment as well as our cost of living.

     Encik Ibrahim bin Othman (Thomson GRC): Sir, I support the plan by Government to sell cooked food and market stalls to existing stallholders. This move will allow stallholders to own their stalls and they would be owners of their place of business, just like the many HDB shopkeepers who have bought their shops from the HDB. They would be able to plan

Column: 1273

their business over the long term and later on, if they feel like giving it up and do something else, they can sell their stalls to others.

    Sir, one area of concern is regarding the valuation of the stalls. The question is: how is the Ministry of the Environment going to assess the value of the stalls located over many different locations. If stallholders do not agree with the valuation, can the Ministry allow them to get a second opinion from other sources? We have many real estate firms which are doing valuation. If not, what other options does the Ministry have?

    Another important concern is the financing aspect. Would the Ministry or any financial institution provide loans to stallholders and allow them to pay over a long period of time with reasonable interest rates? I am afraid if the stalls are very expensive, stallholders may have to pay very high monthly instalments as compared to their present monthly rentals. This inevitably will result in stallholders increasing their prices of goods and consumers will have to bear the burden of price increases.

    Finally, Sir, I wish to ask the Minister regarding the designation of stalls. Now we have cooked food centres and market stalls designated for selling Muslim food and halal market produce. What is the percentage of those stalls now? I hope the Ministry will ensure that all food centres and markets have a fixed percentage of stalls selling Muslim food and halal market produce. The percentage of these stalls can vary from location to location, for example, a higher percentage in Geylang, Tampines or Bedok, where there is a large number of Muslim residents. I believe we must ensure that there will be enough stalls for Muslims to patronise. I wish to ask the Minister how can we ensure that these stalls are not sold and thereafter operated as non-Muslim stalls.
1.45 pm

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Sir, at last year's National Day rally, the Prime Minister announced that the Government would sell hawker stalls to the stallholders at 20-30% below market value. Based on

Column: 1274

feedback I have received, many hawkers are happy with the announcement and are eagerly looking forward to buying the stalls. However, since then very little information on the matter is available. As property prices are skyrocketing all the while, many of the hawkers who intend to buy the stalls they are operating now are worried that soon the stalls may be priced beyond their means.

    Could the Minister please allay the fear of these potential buyers of the stalls? Also, would the Government consider allowing them to use part of their CPF savings to pay for the stalls if they have CPF savings? And what about the hawkers who are unable to raise enough fund to purchase the stalls they are operating now? Will they be allowed to continue renting them? If not, they will be most unfairly deprived of their means of livelihood. May I ask the Minister what is the alternative plan for these hawkers who are unable to purchase the stalls?

    Sir, there will also be hawkers who may want to call it a day by giving up their business, maybe for health or for old age reasons. Some may find such a sale scheme not attractive enough and want to give up their trade. In such cases, may I suggest that the Government offer them a cash grant so that they can gracefully retire from their hawking business.

     Mr Chin Harn Tong: Sir, I understand all hawkers and their assistants undergo a course on food hygiene before they are given their respective licences. Despite this food hygiene course, some hawkers and their assistants are later suspended or fined because of poor food hygiene.

    If the food hygiene course has no lasting effect, the Ministry's requirement of medical examination for persons applying to be hawkers has to be relooked at. The hawkers or hawker assistants do not have to undergo any more medical examination after getting their licences. If they subsequently suffer from a contagious or infectious ailment, such as tuberculosis, the Ministry will not know. Perhaps the Ministry should consider regular or periodic medical check-ups, including X-ray, for hawkers and help to keep health care cost down for the customers of hawkers.

Column: 1275



    Moreover, the Ministry's enforcement machinery seems to have overlooked food vendors who do not ply at food centres. An example is the food vendors who ply at various trade fairs and retail outlets. Then there are the food vendors who appear whenever there are festivals.

    The danger such food vendors pose to their customers is two-fold. The first is that some of these food vendors may have obtained their supplies from dubious sources because of lower costs. The second is that the food vendors do not prepare and cook their food at the points of sale but elsewhere. There is always a very real danger of such food being manufactured or prepared and cooked in unhygienic conditions. The customers who eat such food may suffer more than an upset stomach.

    The Ministry's effort to enforce the ban on the sale of unhygienic food in Singapore is not likely to succeed unless all possible loopholes are plugged. A very recent press report stated that 47 persons were hospitalised for food poisoning after eating in an Orchard Road hotel. This report, unless untrue, speaks for itself. I hope the Ministry will appreciate that the enforcement of food hygiene is important not only in food centres but also in five-star hotels and restaurants.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, a Green Labelling Scheme was launched in 1992 to promote green consumerism. The response of consumers to the green products sold under this scheme would be a good gauge of not only how successful the scheme is, but also the level of environmental awareness among Singaporeans. May I have a progress report on green labelling from the Minister?

    Sir, may I carry on with the other amendment?

     The Chairman: Yes.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: When we were passing the law on CWO (Corrective Work Order) in September 1992, the then Minister for the Environment made it clear

Column: 1276

that CWO is only meant for those recalcitrant and serious offenders. Since its implementation, we have seen a noticeable shift in how it is being enforced. Places where CWO is executed have changed from public beaches to housing estates. The types of littering offences for which CWO is applied have changed from bulky items to just a piece of paper.

    I am not saying that these changes are wrong. But many people are concerned that CWO may be applied indiscriminately. Enforcement action is usually left to the discretion of the environment officer. I have come across a case where there is clearly no intention of littering when an object is left behind but the officer simply would not reason and went ahead to book the person. So will we come to a stage where CWO will be applied on people who accidentally drop a small paper tab from their parking coupon? Where is the limit? Could the Minister please explain?

     Mr Teo Chong Tee: Sir, dengue fever is posing a perennial threat to our health. However, thanks to the vigilance of the Ministry of the Environment and its public education on the spread and prevention of the disease, it has never been allowed to spread to epidemic proportion. But are the preventive actions adequate? There are still reports of outbreaks of the disease in scattered areas in Singapore. As the Aedes mosquitoes, which carry the disease breed in clear water, and mostly indoors, more stringent measures must be taken to stop the breeding in homes. Could the Minister enlighten the House whether the disease is now under control?

    Sir, on the subject of mosquito-transmitted disease, there were reports that a number of people in Ponggol had been infected with malaria last year. Recently, malaria cases have also been reported in the southern and eastern parts of Singapore. Can the Ministry of the Environment assure us that the disease will not pose a threat to us as it used to be years ago? This assurance is important because, according to the World Health Organisation, the organism that is responsible for malaria has developed resistance

Column: 1277

to once effective drugs, such as quinine. This present drug-resistant strain of the organism poses a much greater danger to human lives than the old organism. And up to now, there still is no vaccine that protects against malaria.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, several Members have raised the subject of privatisation of hawker centres. I would like to respond to them first.

    Since the Prime Minister announced that Government would sell hawker stalls to the stallholders so that they, like other Singaporeans, can own assets and have a stake in the country, my Ministry, together with HDB and JTC, has been examining various ways to implement this policy. We have also received many suggestions from Members of Parliament, from hawkers themselves through their association and through other organisations like the Federation of Merchants Association. We are close to finalising the details and will be ready to announce the details of the scheme very soon. However, today I would like to spell out the broad principles of the scheme.

    First of all, let me clarify that it is not quite accurate to describe the scheme as a privatisation of hawker centres. The Government's plan is to enable the incumbent hawkers to own the stalls that they are now renting. As owners, the hawkers would be able to better take care of their centres. They will be more motivated in the running of their own stalls. They can plan long term, they can improve their stalls, they can try out new ways of doing business. This way, they will directly benefit because they can attract more customers and the value of their stalls will go up. At the same time, the customers will also benefit as the hawkers come up with more innovative ways to serve them better.

    At the moment, my Ministry requires stallholders to be present personally at their stalls. Subletting is not allowed. Stalls are not transferable. The reason is that rents are heavily subsidised. Government will remove these restrictions for those stalls which are sold. The hawkers can then sublet, they can sell,

Column: 1278

they can pass the stalls on to their children, if they so wish. With this freeing up, the net result would be that the stalls can be operated for longer hours. Stall-owners can also earn additional income from the subletting and the use of the stalls will be maximised as it is open for longer hours, meaning added convenience for consumers.

    The criteria for the sale of the stalls are that it will only be sold in centres which are not affected by redevelopment in the foreseeable future. We have received quite a number of suggestions from CASE and grassroots organisations on this possibility of withholding the sale to stallholders who profiteer, who harass customers, who flout hygiene rules and so on. These requests are now being studied by my Ministry.

    Then there is the question of the period of ownership which Dr John Chen and several others raised. Sir, in considering the period of ownership for the stallholders, there are two considerations. First of all, we have to take into account the need to have a reasonably long period in order to enable stallholders to plan long term, as I said just now. But on the other hand, the longer the period of ownership the higher will be the purchase price and therefore the less affordable will the stalls be. So weighing these two considerations, my Ministry has decided that the ownership period will be 20 years.

    The sale of the stall scheme will not be implemented overnight. It will be implemented over a period of some 10 years. But this time-frame can be changed. If the response is very positive, we will be in a position to shorten that time-frame.
2.00 pm

    Encik Othman asked how the value of the stalls will be fixed. The Chief Valuer will assess the value of the stalls, taking into account several factors: the location of the stalls, the potential for rental of the stalls, and other factors. There will be a discount. Stalls will be sold at a discount from this valuation. But the final selling prices will be affordable. We have discussed the principles of the scheme with various financial institutions and I

Column: 1279

understand that they are willing to come up with financial packages which will help hawkers to buy over their stalls.

    The Member for Changi also asked whether CPF savings can be used. I will refer this matter to my colleague, the Minister for Labour, for his consideration. However, I am given to understand that the CPF Board has some rules regarding the ownership period before CPF funds can be used. However, let me reiterate what I mentioned earlier, which is that the Government, first of all, will be selling the stalls at a discount. Secondly, financial institutions will be willing to come forward to work out packages to make the final selling price affordable. I am confident that, with these measures, hawkers will be able to buy over their stalls and enjoy the full benefits of the sale scheme.

    With regard to the suggestion to allow stallholders to continue renting their stalls if they, for one reason or another, do not wish to become stallholders, although the hawkers will not be stall owners, I think we can see how we can vary the terms to allow them the other benefits of the sale scheme, such as freeing-up the rules on sub-letting.

    Encik Othman also asked whether we will have a second opinion on the valuation. If any hawker believes that the valuation is excessive, he can request that his stall be put up for tender. He can then bid for it and if he is successful, he will be eligible for the same amount of discount as if he had bought it earlier. If he is unsuccessful, he will be offered a stall in the centres which are not in the sale scheme or he can then opt for a cash grant, if he is eligible.

    The other question from the Member for Thomson GRC was regarding Muslim stalls (halal stalls). Such stalls are now already sited away from sensitive non-halal stalls. This arrangement will continue. We will continue to have provision of stalls catering for Muslim customers. At the same time, we will make sure that the value of the Muslim

Column: 1280

stalls would not be prejudiced by this arrangement.

    Many Members, including Mr Chin Harn Tong, have expressed very grave concerns about the impact of this scheme on food prices. Let me reiterate that the purpose of Government's move to sell hawker stalls is to allow hawkers to own their business and, in the process, they must work at improving their service and bringing in more customers. This must bring considerable benefits not only to the stall owners, but also to their customers. This scheme will radically alter or change the way that they do business. I do not see how this will lead to hefty price increases if we maintain a large number of hawker stalls. There are some 23,000 hawker stalls in the various estates - Government, HDB and JTC hawker centres. There are another 13,000 similar stalls in the private sector. This is a very, very large number of stalls. There is intense competition among them. This intense competition has kept food prices stable and I believe it will continue to be so. In fact, the food prices at private outlets are only marginally higher than those of the Government, HDB and JTC hawker centres, even though their rents are very, very much higher.

    Just to give Members an example. We did a recent survey and we assessed that the median monthly stall rental for private outlets was close to $2,000, something like $1,850. You compare this with the subsidised rental of $120 at Government stalls. There is a gap of something like 15 times. Despite this very large difference, the prices at private outlets, according to this survey, were not significantly higher than those in the Government hawker centres. Then, besides the hawker stalls, there are of course other private food outlets like the fast food centres, the air-conditioned food centres. The prices charged by hawker stalls cannot be higher than those of such food centres and air-conditioned centres which have better facilities.

    What I am saying is that there is a natural cap on hawker food prices. And in the final analysis, we cannot get away from the fact that it is the customers who can exercise the prerogative, although Mr

Column: 1281

Chin makes the point that it is not always easy to exercise that prerogative, and I grant that in some cases, this may be so. But, nevertheless, at the end of the day, there is a limit to what customers are prepared to pay for their hawker food.

    Sir, when the sale of hawker stalls is completed, the Government expects that there will be about 20,000 Singaporeans who will own the stalls that they operate. They will join the growing rank of citizens who are proud owners of valuable assets, like HDB flats, HDB shops, Telecom shares. They too will own a part of Singapore and they too will have a stake in our future prosperity.

     The Chairman: Mr Mah, we do not have much time left.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, let me very quickly take the other points that were raised.

    First of all, Dr John Chen asked about the green labelling scheme. The scheme has now gone on for about a year. It has been well received. It is supported by industries and by members of the public. We have received many applications and at the moment, there are 105 products which carry the green label. We did a survey in February of this year, which showed that six out of 25 distributors reported increase in the sales of their green label products. I believe that this scheme is working well and we should persevere with it.

    He also talked about CWOs. I think it is necessary for me to explain to the Member that whether a person leaves behind a piece of paper or a banana peel or drops it on the pavement deliberately, both are acts of littering. The law is very clear about this. In fact, in the Environmental Public Health Act, it says that any person who has deposited, placed, dropped, left behind or thrown away any refuse in a public place is deemed to have committed an offence under this Act.

    I would like to assure the Member that the CWO is served only on litterbugs who are recalcitrant or who have committed serious littering offences. Not all offenders are served with the CWO. And in 1993,

Column: 1282

only 7% of the 4,000-odd litterbugs were caught and were served with the CWO. So the perception that CWOs are casually served is not quite correct.

    Sir, I would ask my Senior Parliamentary Secretary to take the other two questions on food hygiene and dengue fever.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Ho Kah Leong): Sir, let me first respond to the points raised by the hon. Member for Aljunied GRC, Mr Chin Harn Tong.

    Sir, Mr Chin has raised several points regarding food hygiene. I can assure the Member that my Ministry has always insisted on high standards of food hygiene in the food retail industry. Every food handler, from a hawker to a chef in a restaurant or in a five-star hotel, is expected to practise good food and personal hygiene. It is a responsibility that they owe to their customers.

    Sir, in fact, a lot of efforts have been made by my Ministry to educate food handlers as well as to encourage them to upgrade and improve their kitchens and housekeeping. The Member is correct in saying that every food handler has to sit for a course in food hygiene and pass a test after that. Today, all 72,000 food handlers registered with my Ministry have passed the course. They are also medically screened periodically, once every three years, to make sure that they are not carriers of any infectious disease.

    Sir, the Member also mentioned about food vendors in trade fairs. My Ministry is fully aware that because of the proliferation of trade fairs in Singapore, the food sold in many of these places is not always up to the hygienic standard expected. In the last six months, 32 stallholders at trade fairs were caught for having unhygienic practices. In January and February alone, there were 18 such offenders. I wish to inform the Member as well as the House that enforcement actions will continue to be taken and an overall review to tighten up the control of this problem is being done.
